I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  The knowledge and support technical assistance (TA) will support the promotion of clean 
energy through the preparation of a road map to accelerate deployment of electric vehicles              
(e-vehicles) and grid integration of battery energy storage systems in India. 
 
2.  The TA aligns with operational priority 3 of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) Strategy 
2030  (tackling  climate  change,  building  climate  and  disaster  resilience,  and  enhancing 
environmental sustainability) by supporting decarbonizing of transport systems and supporting 
India’s transition to a cleaner energy mix through adoption of grid-integrated battery storage 
systems.1 The TA is included in ADB’s country operations business plan for India, 2021–2023,2 
supports  ADB’s  country  partnership  strategy  for  India,  2018–2022,3 and  is  consistent  with 
government strategies and flagship programs.4 The Government of India submitted a request for 
this TA on 30 July 2020.5 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
3.  Air pollution in India is a serious health issue. Of the 30 most polluted cities in the world in 
2019, 21 were in India, with one-quarter of this pollution arising from vehicles.6 India’s mobility 
system has many of the fundamental prerequisites for adopting electric-mobility (e-mobility) 
architecture, including low rates of private vehicle ownership, high rates of shared mobility, a large 
share of nonmotorized transit, and diverse modes of transport. E-vehicles have zero tailpipe 
emissions; reduce local street-level air pollution, especially in cities; and can act as mobile energy 
storage services.7 The government has created momentum through its Faster Adoption and 
Manufacturing of Hybrid and Electric Vehicles initiative, which encourages and in some segments 
mandates the adoption of e-vehicles, with a goal of reaching 30% e-vehicle penetration by 2030. 
The initiative creates incentives for e-vehicles and encourages the deployment of charging 
infrastructure in urban centers. Realizing these objectives by 2030 will result in carbon dioxide 
emission reductions of 846 million tons over the lifetime of these e-vehicles.8 However, India 
accounts for only about 0.2% of the global e-vehicle stock. The Indian e-vehicle market is still in 
its nascent stage and is dominated by two-wheelers and three-wheelers, with about 0.4 million 
electric two wheelers, 0.1 million e-rickshaws, and 7,000 electric cars. 
 
4.  Lower e-vehicle penetration can be attributed primarily to a lack of adequate e-vehicle 
charging  infrastructure  and  high  upfront  costs  of  e-vehicles.    While  e-vehicle  charging 
infrastructure is being ramped up, the challenge of high initial purchasing prices can be tackled 
through increased battery manufacturing capacity. Since the battery accounts for about one-third 
of the total purchase price of an e-vehicle, driving down battery costs through rapid scale-up of 
production and standardizing battery components will be key to the long-term success of India’s 
automotive sector, with knock-on benefits for energy storage development (mobile storage, and

2 
repurposing of e-vehicle batteries for second-life stationary storage). India’s market for e-vehicle 
batteries alone could be worth as much as $300 billion by 2030.9 India could represent more than 
one-third of global e-vehicle battery demand by 2030 if the country meets its goal of rapidly 
transitioning to shared, connected, and electric mobility. Driving down battery costs will not only 
impact e-vehicle demand but will also contribute to enhanced renewable energy integration at the 
grid level through deployment of energy storage. 
 
5.  Deployment  of  battery  technologies  is  highly  synergistic  with  e-vehicle  deployment; 
pursuing these in a coordinated manner will be critical to meeting the e-mobility-driven increase 
in electricity demand through sustainable renewable energy integrated at the grid level. The 
government has established an ambitious target of 175 gigawatts (GW) of installed renewable 
energy capacity by 2022, which includes 60 GW of wind and 100 GW of solar, up from capacities 
of about 35 GW of wind and 26 GW of solar in 2019. The government targets 450 GW of installed 
renewable energy capacity by 2030.10 India’s electrical grid will have to evolve accordingly to 
meet this ambitious target without compromising stability or reliability. Solar and wind power are 
intermittent in nature, and the timing of their output can be predicted with some accuracy, but the 
time-of-use cannot be controlled without improved energy storage. Because of this, integration of 
renewable  energy  into  the  grid  at  such  a  scale  will  face  several  challenges,  including 
instantaneous changes in plant output, daily and seasonal variation in energy output, daily and 
seasonal variation in demand, and nonconcurrence of generation and demand peaks. Battery 
storage has proven to be reliable for short-term grid stability and back-up power (e.g., at the 100-
megawatt Hornsdale facility in Australia), reducing the need for fossil-fuel peaking plants; the 
batteries for these applications can be stationary or mobile, although mobile storage has yet to 
be deployed at scale in developing countries.  
 
6.   E-vehicles will require flexible usage of charging infrastructure backed by consistent 
power from the grid. Installation of charging infrastructure for e-vehicles presents both challenges 
and opportunities: a growing e-vehicle fleet will increase stress on the grid, creating a need for 
intelligent charging systems; at the same time, e-vehicles represent mobile energy storage, 
providing grid stability by absorbing the variable output from solar and wind generation. Battery 
storage systems form the critical link in an integrated e-vehicle and renewable-energy-driven 
solution to address air pollution and promote the longer-term decarbonization of India’s economy. 
It is estimated that India’s carbon dioxide emissions will double by 2030 compared to 2012.11 
Addressing a problem of this scale will require a multipronged approach through synergistic 
investments in battery technologies and e-vehicles to complement investments in variable-output 
renewable energy. Governments need to make or facilitate investments in battery technologies 
and e-vehicle projects to power generation companies, power distribution companies, and other 
stakeholders. Developing projects that are both technically and commercially feasible will attract 
investors and ensure more clean energy in India’s energy generation mix.12 Power distribution 
companies are well-positioned in the value chain to provide improved electricity services accruing 
from battery energy technologies, while generating revenue through the provision of electricity as 
a transport fuel via charging infrastructure.

3 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
7.  The TA is aligned with the following impact: air quality in cities and uptake of renewable 
energy and storage solutions improved (footnote 4). The TA will have the following outcome: 
accelerated deployment of e-vehicles and battery energy storage systems.13 The TA will support 
preparation of road maps for accelerated deployment of e-vehicles and battery energy storage in 
selected states.14  
 
B.  Outputs, Methods, and Activities 
 
8.  Output 1: Integrated development plan for promoting electric vehicles created. This 
output will address key impediments to e-vehicle adoption in India. E-vehicle supply chain 
analysis and a survey of the automotive industry will be conducted to understand and address 
the key issues that are preventing the shift toward an e-vehicle-based mobility system. The 
analysis will be further supplemented by global benchmark studies to address “pain points” in the 
Indian market that are hindering large-scale adoption of e-vehicles. As any marked shift in the 
automotive sector has employment and labor skills implications, wide stakeholder consultations 
at the central and state level will be carried out to understand and address gaps—e.g., by 
upgrading  the  skills  of  staff  across  different  segments  of  the  automotive  industry  through 
workshops, who in turn can help support cleaner e-vehicle-based mobility systems. The survey 
of the automotive industry will also address the perceived impact of e-vehicle adoption on 
transport companies and independent owners of three-wheeler and four-wheeler rickshaws and 
taxi fleets/units. The TA will support carrying out of analysis on potential incentive schemes, 
including enhancing the availability of credit facilities for e-vehicles. Gender-related elements will 
be incorporated as appropriate; these may include ensuring the participation of women in training 
and capacity-building activities. Similarly, proper management of old e-vehicle batteries and units 
will be assessed and best practices shared to ensure that these cheap, old units will not simply 
be relegated to rural or newly urbanized towns (thereby increasing pollution in those towns). 
 
9.  Output 2: Road map for deployment of battery technologies developed.  This output 
will support electricity distribution companies and/or other entities to develop a strategy for 
adopting battery technologies and systems that will encourage e-vehicle deployment and lead to 
a higher percentage of renewables in the energy mix. The techno-commercial aspects of various 
battery technologies and limitations of the current system will be analyzed. This output will also 
support and encourage public companies to go green and reduce their carbon footprints by 
investing in improved battery technologies. The output will look at how to properly dispose of 
and/or reuse old batteries and assess the environmental and climate impacts of battery power at 
all stages of the battery life cycle. Activities will support the development of a robust battery 
storage market in the country and in selected states to meet the requirements of an electrical grid 
with a large renewable energy mix in the overall energy portfolio. Development and deployment 
of battery technologies will promote e-vehicles in the country. Prospects for joint ventures or 
technology partnerships with established technology-leading companies in other countries will be 
explored as part of the road map preparation.

14 States will be selected based on criteria to be developed, which will include but not be limited to a state’s interest in 
the project, its plans to promote e-vehicles and battery storage, and complementarity with other ongoing efforts.

4 
10.  Innovative aspects  of  project  design.  The  TA  will support  activities  that  address 
bottlenecks preventing the scale-up of e-vehicles and battery technologies in India. Through 
partnerships  with  the  government’s  central  planning  agency—the  National  Institution  for 
Transforming India (NITI Aayog)—power distribution companies, and other key players in the       
e-vehicle–renewable energy value chain, the TA project will help the government meet its clean 
energy  targets.  By  pursuing  battery  energy  technologies  and  e-vehicle  development  in  a 
coordinated manner, the TA will facilitate identification of new investment opportunities in charging 
infrastructure, stationary storage (including repurposing of used e-vehicle batteries for second-life 
storage), vehicle-to-grid systems and services, storage-enabled power trading, and more. This 
will build on efforts by ADB projects through Energy Efficiency Services Limited in India for 
promotion of e-vehicles and charging stations along with promotion of various demand-side 
energy efficiency investments, and on biofuels with Indian Oil Company Limited to provide 
synergetic response. The TA will focus on creating demand and enable greater deployment of 
battery technologies and e-vehicles rather than vehicle manufacturing.  
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
11.  The TA is estimated to cost $1,000,000 which will be financed on a grant basis by the 
Asian  Clean  Energy  Fund 15 under  the  Clean  Energy  Financing  Partnership  Facility  and 
administered by ADB. The key expenditure items are listed in Appendix 2. 
 
12.  Eligible expenditures include (i) consultant services; and (ii) non-consultant costs for local 
training, workshops, minimal equipment such as computers, and operating costs essential to carry 
out the TA, including rent of vehicles, if justified. 
  
13.  The government will provide counterpart support in the form of counterpart staff, office 
accommodation, and other in-kind contributions. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
14.  ADB will administer the TA and NITI Aayog will be the executing agency. ADB will engage 
both national and international consultants. ADB will carry out TA administration, supervision, 
implementation oversight, and communication with consultants and stakeholders.

IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
18.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the Asian 
Development  Bank  administering  technical  assistance  not  exceeding  the  equivalent  of 
$1,000,000 to India to be financed on a grant basis by the Asian Clean Energy Fund under the 
Clean  Energy  Financing  Partnership  Facility  for  Promoting  Clean  Energy  Usage  through 
Enhanced Adoption of Electric Vehicles and Grid Integration of Battery Energy Storage Systems, 
and hereby reports this action to the Board.

Key Activities with Milestones 
1.  Integrated development plans for promoting electric vehicles created 
1.1.  Analyze existing credit lines for e-vehicle purchase and suggest measures for increased credit 
availability for e-vehicle purchase and adoption (Q2 2021). 
1.2.  Undertake a comprehensive stakeholder analysis, hold consultation meetings with key automotive 
stakeholders, including relevant national- and state-level automobile manufacturers’ associations, 
automobile  associations,  and  Indian  auto  trade  unions,  as  needed,  and  come  up  with 
recommendations for development of e-vehicles through cost-effective technologies (Q2 2021). 
1.3.  Gather relevant data on global e-vehicle technologies and trends; suggest best practices that can 
be adopted in India (Q2–Q3 2021). 
1.4.  Undertake desk review and expert consultations to conduct in-depth analysis for promoting shift 
toward electric mobility across segments (Q4 2021). 
1.5.  Conduct stakeholder consultations and workshops, including with key civil society organizations, 
such as auto manufacturers’ associations and auto unions, to analyze the re-skilling requirements 
for e-vehicle-based mobility in cities (Q2 2022). 
1.6.  Conduct  in-depth  review,  research,  and  recommendations  on  global  e-vehicle  infrastructure 
models and suggest recommendations for adoption of best practices in India (Q4 2023). 
1.7.  Develop,  discuss,  and  finalize  training  modules  on  e-vehicle/e-vehicle-infra  operation  and 
maintenance (Q1 2025). 
 
2.  Road map for deployment of battery technologies developed 
2.1.  Conduct in-depth review, research, and recommendations on battery storage infrastructure models 
being adopted globally and suggest recommendations for adoption of best practices in India (Q3 
2021). 
2.2.  Design a strategy for using battery-based energy storage systems for selected companies (Q1 
2024). 
2.3.  Conduct stakeholder consultations to present draft/preliminary recommendations for implementing 
battery storage (Q1 2025).
